newsitem.title: USA: US West Coast products ease more, buyers sidelined.
newsitem.headline: US West Coast products ease more, buyers sidelined.

text.p: U.S. West Coast product prices drifted lower late on Thursday, with recent fluctuations in futures markets sidelining local trade, while some distillates benefitted from tightened supplies.
"No one was anxious to do anything," one Arizona-based trader said.
He was surprised that prices for low sulphur diesel, which is used outside California, failed to make gains with supplies supposedly lean in Las Vegas, Nevada.
Low sulphur, or "EPA" diesel, slipped 1.0 to 1.50 cents a gallon to 71/72.00 cents.

But CARB diesel, used in California, bucked the bearish trend in products by gaining one cent late to end 78/79 cents a gallon. Rumours that a products ship was "drydocked" in San Francisco made L.A. supply leaner.
Meanwhile, heating oil for October delivery retreated from new highs to end the day down 0.87 cent at 70.90 cents.
Profit-taking and fading interest in expiring October products contracts pressured the market.
November crude oil and front-month gasoline also dropped in line with heating oil

Wholesale prices for conventional regular gasoline in Los Angeles erased Wednesday's gain by falling a penny early, then staying flat at 66/67 cents in the afternoon. San Francisco grades were 2.75 cents lower than L.A. material.
Consumption of conventional gasoline will drop in coming weeks as interior Western states add more oxygenates to car fuels and cut back on straight gasoline use.
"It will lower the demand for gasoline by 10 percent," in the Phoenix, Arizona-area, one trader said.
CARB gasoline in L.A. eased 0.50 cent to 71.50/72.00 cents a gallon. -- David Brinkerhoff, Los Angeles bureau +1 213 380 2014
